member.name: P:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.FieldMask.MergeOptions.ReplaceMessageFields
member.summary: Whether to replace message fields(i.e., discard existing content in destination message fields) when merging. Default behavior is to merge the source message field into the destination message field.

member.name: P:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.FieldMask.MergeOptions.ReplaceRepeatedFields
member.summary: Whether to replace repeated fields (i.e., discard existing content in destination repeated fields) when merging. Default behavior is to append elements from source repeated field to the destination repeated field.

member.name: P:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.FieldMask.MergeOptions.ReplacePrimitiveFields
member.summary:
Whether to replace primitive (non-repeated and non-message) fields in destination message fields with the source primitive fields (i.e., if the field is set in the source, the value is copied to the destination; if the field is unset in the source, the field is cleared from the destination) when merging.
Default behavior is to always set the value of the source primitive field to the destination primitive field, and if the source field is unset, the default value of the source field is copied to the destination.

member.name: T:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Struct
member.summary:
`Struct` represents a structured data value, consisting of fields which map to dynamically typed values. In some languages, `Struct` might be supported by a native representation. For example, in scripting languages like JS a struct is represented as an object. The details of that representation are described together with the proto support for the language.
The JSON representation for `Struct` is JSON object.

member.name: T:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Value
member.summary:
`Value` represents a dynamically typed value which can be either null, a number, a string, a boolean, a recursive struct value, or a list of values. A producer of value is expected to set one of these variants. Absence of any variant indicates an error.
The JSON representation for `Value` is JSON value.

member.name: M:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp.ToDateTime
member.summary: Converts this timestamp into a .
member.remarks: The resulting DateTime will always have a Kind of Utc. If the timestamp is not a precise number of ticks, it will be truncated towards the start of time. For example, a timestamp with a value of 99 will result in a value precisely on a second.
member.returns: This timestamp as a DateTime.
member.exception: The timestamp contains invalid values; either it is incorrectly normalized or is outside the valid range.

member.name: M:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp.ToDateTimeOffset
member.summary: Converts this timestamp into a .
member.remarks: The resulting DateTimeOffset will always have an Offset of zero. If the timestamp is not a precise number of ticks, it will be truncated towards the start of time. For example, a timestamp with a value of 99 will result in a value precisely on a second.
member.returns: This timestamp as a DateTimeOffset.
member.exception: The timestamp contains invalid values; either it is incorrectly normalized or is outside the valid range.

member.summary: Converts the specified to a .
member.exception: The Kind of is not DateTimeKind.Utc.
member.returns: The converted timestamp.

member.summary: Converts the given to a
member.remarks: The offset is taken into consideration when converting the value (so the same instant in time is represented) but is not a separate part of the resulting value. In other words, there is no roundtrip operation to retrieve the original DateTimeOffset.
member.param: The date and time (with UTC offset) to convert to a timestamp.
member.returns: The converted timestamp.

member.name: M:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp.ToJson(System.Int64,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts a timestamp specified in seconds/nanoseconds to a string.
member.remarks: If the value is a normalized duration in the range described in timestamp.proto, is ignored. Otherwise, if the parameter is true, a JSON object with a warning is returned; if it is false, an is thrown.
member.param: Seconds portion of the duration.
Nanoseconds portion of the duration.
Determines the handling of non-normalized values
member.exception: The represented duration is invalid, and is false.

member.name: M:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp.CompareTo(Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp)
member.summary: Given another timestamp, returns 0 if the timestamps are equivalent, -1 if this timestamp precedes the other, and 1 otherwise
member.remarks: Make sure the timestamps are normalized. Comparing non-normalized timestamps is not specified and may give unexpected results.
member.param: Timestamp to compare
member.returns: an integer indicating whether this timestamp precedes or follows the other

member.name: M:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp.op_LessThan(Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp,Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp)
member.summary: Compares two timestamps and returns whether the first is less than (chronologically precedes) the second
member.remarks: Make sure the timestamps are normalized. Comparing non-normalized timestamps is not specified and may give unexpected results.
member.returns: true if a precedes b

member.name: M:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp.op_GreaterThan(Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp,Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp)
member.summary: Compares two timestamps and returns whether the first is greater than (chronologically follows) the second

member.returns: true if a follows b

member.summary: Compares two timestamps and returns whether the first is less than (chronologically precedes) the second

member.returns: true if a precedes b

member.summary: Compares two timestamps and returns whether the first is greater than (chronologically follows) the second

member.returns: true if the two timestamps refer to the same nanosecond

member.name: M:Google.Protobuf.WellKnownTypes.Timestamp.ToDiagnosticString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of this for diagnostic purposes.
member.remarks: Normally the returned value will be a JSON string value (including leading and trailing quotes) but when the value is non-normalized or out of range, a JSON object representation will be returned instead, including a warning. This is to avoid exceptions being thrown when trying to diagnose problems - the regular JSON formatter will still throw an exception for non-normalized values.
member.returns: A string representation of this value.

member.name: T:Google.Protobuf.WireFormat
member.summary:
This class is used internally by the Protocol Buffer Library and generated message implementations. It is public only for the sake of those generated messages. Others should not use this class directly.
This class contains constants and helper functions useful for dealing with the Protocol Buffer wire format.

member.name: M:Google.Protobuf.WritingPrimitives.EncodeZigZag32(System.Int32)
member.summary: Encode a 32-bit value with ZigZag encoding.
member.remarks: ZigZag encodes signed integers into values that can be efficiently encoded with varint. (Otherwise, negative values must be sign-extended to 64 bits to be varint encoded, thus always taking 10 bytes on the wire.)

member.name: M:Google.Protobuf.WritingPrimitives.EncodeZigZag64(System.Int64)
member.summary: Encode a 64-bit value with ZigZag encoding.
member.remarks: ZigZag encodes signed integers into values that can be efficiently encoded with varint. (Otherwise, negative values must be sign-extended to 64 bits to be varint encoded, thus always taking 10 bytes on the wire.)

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.DynamicallyAccessedMembersAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that certain members on a specified are accessed dynamically, for example through .
member.remarks:
This allows tools to understand which members are being accessed during the execution of a program.
This attribute is valid on members whose type is or .
When this attribute is applied to a location of type , the assumption is that the string represents a fully qualified type name.
When this attribute is applied to a class, interface, or struct, the members specified can be accessed dynamically on instances returned from calling on instances of that class, interface, or struct.
If the attribute is applied to a method it's treated as a special case and it implies the attribute should be applied to the "this" parameter of the method. As such the attribute should only be used on instance methods of types assignable to System.Type (or string, but no methods will use it there).

member.summary: Gets the which specifies the type of members dynamically accessed.

This enumeration has a attribute that allows a bitwise combination of its member values.

member.remarks: This allows tools to understand which methods are unsafe to call when removing unreferenced code from an application.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute
member.summary: Suppresses reporting of a specific rule violation, allowing multiple suppressions on a single code artifact.
member.remarks: is different than in that it doesn't have a . So it is always preserved in the compiled assembly.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.#ctor(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class, specifying the category of the tool and the identifier for an analysis rule.
member.param: The category for the attribute.
The identifier of the analysis rule the attribute applies to.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Category
member.summary: Gets the category identifying the classification of the attribute.
member.remarks: The property describes the tool or tool analysis category for which a message suppression attribute applies.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.CheckId
member.summary: Gets the identifier of the analysis tool rule to be suppressed.
member.remarks: Concatenated together, the and properties form a unique check identifier.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Scope
member.summary: Gets or sets the scope of the code that is relevant for the attribute.
member.remarks: The Scope property is an optional argument that specifies the metadata scope for which the attribute is relevant.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Target
member.summary: Gets or sets a fully qualified path that represents the target of the attribute.
member.remarks: The property is an optional argument identifying the analysis target of the attribute. An example value is "System.IO.Stream.ctor():System.Void". Because it is fully qualified, it can be long, particularly for targets such as parameters. The analysis tool user interface should be capable of automatically formatting the parameter.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.MessageId
member.summary: Gets or sets an optional argument expanding on exclusion criteria.
member.remarks: The property is an optional argument that specifies additional exclusion where the literal metadata target is not sufficiently precise. For example, the cannot be applied within a method, and it may be desirable to suppress a violation against a statement in the method that will give a rule violation, but not against all statements in the method.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Justification
member.summary: Gets or sets the justification for suppressing the code analysis message.
